results.title: Licence to kill (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Glen, Michael G. Wilson, Albert R. Broccoli, United Artists Corporation and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
The happy nuptials of James’ CIA buddy Felix Leiter (David Hedison) and bride-to-be Della are rudely interrupted when they embark on a mercy dash to capture drug lord Franz Sanchez (Robert Davi). Thanks to some aerial fishing though, their mission is successful and the parachuting groomsmen make it in time for the wedding. The happy couple are soon devastated however when Sanchez escapes and kills the bride and maims the groom as payback. This triggers best buddy James (Timothy Dalton) to relinquish his secret service status and licence to kill authority (Bond is under orders to complete another mission) as he embarks on a personal vendetta to revenge Sanchez’s brutality towards his friends. Ably assisted by ex-Army pilot Pam Bouvier (Carey Lowell), Bond flies into Isthmus City to infiltrate himself into Sanchez’s posse where he discovers a television evangelist (Wayne Newton) providing a front for cocaine dealing. Featuring a plethora of water inspired stunts earlier on in the film, the cast also includes Benicio Del Toro as a brooding henchman and Talisa Soto as Lupe Lamore, Sanchez’s mistress, eye candy, and source of jealousy for Bouvier. This was Timothy Dalton’s last appearance as Bond.

results.title: Jem Cohen: early works
results.brief_description: A rich and haunting collection of early works from an artist who paints with fragments of image and sound from New York street life. Dogs, passing cars, the homeless, drugged and alienated people drift through these works, in the rhythms of their own time. Simple mysteries are uncovered through a window, in half deserted streets, and in wind blown garbage. Voices become confessions, shadows become cinematic and we are absorbed and compiled into a world of wonder, in which people inevitably leave traces - and lists.

results.title: Janus. Eps 15 and 16: Suicide by cop. Intent to permanently deprive
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 15 and 16 of the television series Janus. “Suicide by cop” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods). Steve Hennnessey is dead and Peter Faithful and his men in the Tactical Response Squad, particularly Danny (Steve Vidler), are now under investigation by the Homicide Squad. Matters become further complicated when new evidence is brought to light implicating both Peter and Danny not following police procedures at the scene of the crime. Extra pressure is also put on Danny when he takes the stand as an informant for a 2 year-old assault case which Tina Bertrum (Tracy Mann) is prosecuting. “Intent to permanently deprive” (49 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Shirl Hennessey is charged with shop-lifting and in possession of a lighter-pistol and appears to want to go down for the crime, much to the bewilderment of Michael Kidd, her Defence Counsellor. Vic Manoulis finds himself involved with a disturbing child abuse murder case. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Robert Wallace, John Arnold and Frank Gallacher.

results.title: Live and let die (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Guy Hamilton, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Live and let die heralded the arrival of Roger Moore as 007, it also featured a pre title sequence in which James Bond does not appear. Instead, there are the deaths of 3 agents, including a funeral procession which turns into street party and murder at a voodoo ceremony. 007 is entrusted with finding a connection between the deaths and travels to Harlem where he is exposed to a network of African Americans working for “Mr Big” (Yaphet Kotto). On the Caribbean island of San Monique he encounters Dr Katanga, owner of a large plantation of opium poppies. Accompanied by inept agent Rosie Carver (Gloria Hendry), Bond only has eyes for Solitaire (Jane Seymour), secret weapon of Dr Katanga’s with her fortune telling capabilities that are in danger of disappearing, should she fall in love. Shot on location in New Orleans (which also dictated a lot of the action sequences), notable scenes include a double decker bus chase, crocodiles snapping at 007’s heels, snakes (of varying degrees of realism), and a hook handed henchman.

results.title: Janus. Eps 09 and 10: A Mischievous offence. A Familiar utterance
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 9 and 10 of the television series Janus. “A Mischievous offence” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) has the eccentric DPP Prosecutor Clyde Martin (Douglas Hedge) at his witty best in the court room scene, playing to the jury, annoying the Defence and humoring the witnesses. The case being handled is a horse ring-in trial and the star witness, an 8 year-old boy. Steve Hennessey is still missing and Peter Faithful offers to do a deal with Kenny Hardy (being held for the armed bank robbery) in exchange for information leading to Steve’s whereabouts. “A Familiar utterance” (50 mins) (directed by Michael Carson). The irony of it all - Michael Kidd, the Hennessey’s barrister, is asked to defend two police (formerly of the Drug Squad) who have been charged with assaulting a bouncer in a night club. Rob Griffin, following a tip off from Prosecutor Clyde Martin, links up with Peter Faithful in tracking down a brief of a 10 year old unsolved murder of Patrick Clancy, best mate of Mal Hennessey. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Jack Finsterer, Elizabeth Welch, Tracy Mann, Jane Menelaus, Michael Edward-Stevens, Damian Foley and David Cotter.

results.title: The Living daylights (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Glen, Michael G. Wilson, Albert R. Broccoli and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Touted as a possible replacement to the outgoing original Bond - Sean Connery - Timothy Dalton gave way to Roger Moore because he thought he looked too young for the role and didn’t appear until 14 years later in “The Living daylights”. Marking a more brutal instalment than usual, the film starts with a game of paintball gone wrong then moves to Czechoslovakia where Bond is entrusted with protecting the life of defecting former KGB agent Georgi Koskov (Jeroen Krabbe) who is being targeted by a sniper. When the sniper turns out to be a beautiful blonde cellist, Bond is content to wing her and pursue her later for further information. Safely back in the UK, Koskov is kidnapped and disappears, but not before he tells British Intelligence of a plot by fellow KGB agent General Leonid Pushkin (John Rhys-Davies) to assassinate British and American agents in a bid to start a nuclear war. 007 is ordered to carry out the termination issued against Pushkin, based on evidence which he considers dubious. When the name of an American arms dealer is mentioned, the plot thickens. Notable scenes include a particularly grisly death by automatic door and tobogganing on a cello case. It was also the last Bond film to use one of Ian Fleming’s original story titles. Cast also includes Maryam D’Abo, Joe Don Baker and Art Malik.

results.title: Janus. Eps 03 and 04: Not on the merits. A Rare crushing reversal
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 3 and 4 of the television series Janus. “Not on the merits” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) continues on the story of the Hennessey’s and police endeavours to convict, in particular, Mal Hennessey. After a protracted police surveillance of Mal Hennnessey, and using a police undercover operant, Peter Faithful and his squad finally video a drug deal, arresting Mal Hennessey and Kirsty Nichols, Steve Hennessey’s girlfriend. Kirsty, under pressure by the police, turns informant/witness for the prosecution. “A Rare crushing reversal” (51 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney) involves once again another arrest of Mal and Steve Hennessey and Darren Mack on drug charges. However Peter Faithful’s witness, Dale Cassidy (Grant Piro), a drug addict who was supplied by the Hennessey’s and who the police offered to put under the witness protection scheme in exchange for information finds that it’s not so easy “dobbing in a mate”. Even more so when he is faced with the continual barrage from the Defence Counsellor, Michael Kidd (Chris Haywood). Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Tracy Mann, Louise Siversen, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Brett Swain.

results.title: Tomorrow never dies [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Roger Spottiswoode, Barbara Broccoli, Michael Wilson and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
The 18th in the Bond series finds Bond (Pierce Brosnan) battling crazed media mogul Elliot Carver (Jonathan Pryce) who is intent on starting a war between England and China. His motivation - covering the event on his global satellite network and gaining kudos as the most powerful in current affairs and global business growth. Michelle Yeoh is the beautiful Wai Lin, a Chinese agent who teams up with Bond after crossing paths with him in her pursuit to find out what Carver really is up to. “Tomorrow never dies” is a fast paced action film full of over the top stunts and the usual comedy and sexual innuendo which will delight fans of 007. Cast also includes Dame Judi Dench, Teri Hatcher and Geoffrey Palmer.

results.title: This is a history of New York
results.brief_description: ‘This is a History of New York’ chronicles the seven ages of mankind from Prehistory to the Space Age. In the Age of Hunters and Gatherers, stray dogs patrol the streets while the homeless forage for food. Later in the Medieval Period, crazed street preachers pace frantically before ominous gothic architecture. The richness of Cohen’s vision is found in this haunting imagery and the perception that the thriving city of New York is really the accumulation of humanity’s failures, as well as triumphs.

results.title: Janus. Eps 25 and 26: Mute by visitation. Elements of murder
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 25 and 26 of the television series Janus. “Mute by visitation” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith). Glenda de Bono is listed to preside as Judge on a retrial of a rape case. This is her first major trial since becoming a County Judge. The unusual aspect of this trial however, is that both the victim, Colleen Maitland (Danni Wright) and the alleged rapist, Tim Lester (Mike Canfield) are profoundly deaf - so are their families and the witnesses. Meanwhile, application for Mal Hennessey’s blood sample for DNA testing is granted and Peter Faithful gets a bonus when “Gazza”, during his interview, puts Shirl Hennessey in the picture as the one to organise the disposal of Patrick Clancy’s body. “Elements of murder” (51 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) is the final episode of Janus. Mal Hennessey and Shirl Hennessey face a commital hearing - Mal for murder and Shirl for accessory after the fact to murder. The use of DNA as corroborating material, and Sandy (Mal’s ex girlfriend), Gazza and Tomlinson as witnesses for the Prosecution, make it almost impossible for Michael Kidd to get Mal and Shirl off. And the internal investigation into Steve Hennessey’s death is closing in on Peter Faithful and his team. A dramatic conclusion to this brilliant Australian television series. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Louise Siversen, Brett Swain, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Leverne McDonnell, Belinda McClory and Victoria Eagger.
